claim: Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic was a founding participant of the UN.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic (USSR) was not an independent state but a constituent republic of the Soviet Union, which was admitted as a single entity to the United Nations in 1945.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic (USSR) was not an independent state but a constituent republic of the Soviet Union, which was admitted as a single entity to the United Nations in 1945.
The Ukrainian SSR held de jure sovereignty during its participation in international organizations prior to 1945 and should therefore be recognized as an independent entity.
The Soviet Union’s admission to the UN did not preclude individual republics from having concurrent diplomatic roles or symbolic representation.
Sovereignty requires recognition by other states and legal independence; no nation recognized the Ukrainian SSR as an independent state before 1991.
Historical records confirm that all constituent republics of the USSR were represented collectively under Moscow’s delegation without separate diplomatic identities.
The absence of formal recognition by major powers undermines claims of de jure sovereignty for any Soviet republic during 1945.
UN archives explicitly state that only three Soviet entities (Russia, Ukraine, Belarus) were granted seats under collective representation during post-war negotiations.

supporting.text: The United Nations Charter specifies that only sovereign states can become founding members, and the Ukrainian SSR lacked full sovereignty during its existence as part of the USSR.

attacks.text: The United Nations Charter specifies that only sovereign states can become founding members, and the Ukrainian SSR lacked full sovereignty during its existence as part of the USSR.
The Ukrainian SSR had de jure sovereignty as a republic within the USSR, recognized by international law.
The USSR's UN membership inherently included its constituent republics, granting them indirect participation in foundational decisions.
The UN Charter's Article 4 does not explicitly require full independence for statehood, only recognition by existing members.
Historical records show that the Ukrainian SSR's sovereignty was not recognized by international law, as it was subordinate to the USSR.
The USSR represented itself as a single entity in the UN, with no evidence of republic-level voting or decision-making authority.
The Soviet Union's admission to the UN in 1945 excluded its republics from direct participation due to their non-sovereign status under international law.
The International Court of Justice has ruled that Soviet republics were not independent states under customary international law.
UN archives from 1945 confirm that only the USSR delegation participated in drafting foundational documents.
Legal scholars consistently note that Soviet republics lacked external diplomatic representation required for UN membership.

supporting.text: Historical records confirm that the Soviet Union (USSR) was one of the original 51 UN members, not its individual republics like Ukraine.

attacks.text: Historical records confirm that the Soviet Union (USSR) was one of the original 51 UN members, not its individual republics like Ukraine.
Ukraine's status as an autonomous republic within the USSR implies it had de facto representation at the UN.
Some historical sources list Ukraine as a founding member alongside the USSR in 1945.
The Ukrainian SSR's participation in UN negotiations during its formation suggests independent involvement.
Autonomy within a union does not equate to independent statehood; only sovereign entities join international organizations.
The cited sources for B2 lack official verification and conflate USSR membership with republican representation.
UN negotiations were conducted exclusively by USSR delegates; no republican representatives held voting rights.
The argument in C1 ignores Soviet constitutional laws requiring centralized diplomatic authority.
B2's sources are from non-academic publications with known biases against Soviet historiography.
C3 misrepresents procedural history; Ukrainian SSR delegates were acting under USSR authority.

supporting.text: The Ukrainian SSR's participation in international organizations was conducted through its parent state, the Soviet Union, which acted on its behalf in global forums.

attacks.text: The Ukrainian SSR's participation in international organizations was conducted through its parent state, the Soviet Union, which acted on its behalf in global forums.
The Soviet Union and Ukrainian SSR were distinct political entities with separate legal identities under international law.
Founding membership in the UN required sovereign state status, which the Ukrainian SSR lacked as a subnational entity of the USSR.
The Soviet Union's delegation at the UN included representatives from all its constituent republics, effectively granting them collective international standing.
The UN Charter explicitly recognized only sovereign states as founding members, not subunits of larger states.
The concept of 'sovereign state' in 1945 explicitly excluded socialist republics within federations from independent membership claims.
Historical records show Ukrainian SSR officials directly participated in UN proceedings without formal Soviet oversight.

supporting.text: The dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 led to Ukraine becoming an independent state and joining the UN separately; this implies prior non-sovereignty.

attacks.text: The dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 led to Ukraine becoming an independent state and joining the UN separately; this implies prior non-sovereignty.
The Ukrainian SSR was not a separate state but an internal administrative division of the Soviet Union, which was recognized as a single sovereign entity by the UN.
The UN Charter explicitly states that only sovereign states can become founding members; constituent republics of a federal state are not independently recognized.
Ukraine's independence in 1991 did not retroactively negate its historical status as part of the USSR; sovereignty is determined by international recognition at time of admission.
The Soviet Union's membership in the UN included all its republics as part of its delegation, but this does not equate to individual participation in foundational treaties.
The UN's admission criteria for founding members prioritized de jure sovereignty over territorial continuity; federal structures do not inherently disqualify participation.
Historical precedent shows that federal states like Yugoslavia or Czechoslovakia were recognized as single entities without granting independent status to their subdivisions.
